title: Dan_Bongino
summary: This article announces that Dan Bongino, a conservative political commentator and former Secret Service agent, has been designated to serve as the next Deputy Director of the FBI starting March 17, 2025, following President Donald Trump's announcement on February 23, 2025. Bongino, who currently hosts shows on Rumble and previously on Fox News, will conclude his media roles on March 14 before assuming this significant position in law enforcement.
extract: Daniel John Bongino is an American conservative political commentator, podcaster, radio host, author, and former law enforcement officer. He is expected to serve as the 20th deputy director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) beginning on March 17, 2025. He hosts The Dan Bongino Show on Rumble and previously hosted Unfiltered with Dan Bongino on Fox News until April 2023.
anthropic_trending_reason: Dan Bongino is trending because President Trump has appointed him as the deputy director of the FBI, effective March 17, 2025. The selection has drawn significant attention as Bongino is transitioning from being a conservative political commentator, podcaster, and media personality to a high-ranking position in federal law enforcement.
openai_trending_reason: Dan Bongino is trending because President Donald Trump has appointed him as the deputy director of the FBI, a decision that has generated significant attention and debate, particularly among Democratic lawmakers. His background as a conservative commentator and former law enforcement officer adds to the controversy surrounding his appointment.

title: Roberta_Flack
summary: This article reports on the death of American singer Roberta Flack, who passed away on February 24, 2025, at age 88. It highlights her influential career as a Grammy-winning artist known for chart-topping hits like "Killing Me Softly with His Song" and her contribution to multiple musical genres.
extract: Roberta Cleopatra Flack was an American singer and pianist known for her emotive, genre-blending ballads that spanned R&B, jazz, folk, and pop and contributed to the birth of quiet storm. Her commercial success included the Billboard Hot 100 chart-topping singles "The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face", "Killing Me Softly with His Song", and "Feel Like Makin' Love". She became the first artist to win the Grammy Award for Record of the Year in consecutive years.
anthropic_trending_reason: Roberta Flack is trending because she died at the age of 88, as reported in multiple news sources this past week. The Grammy-winning singer, known for hits like "Killing Me Softly With His Song" and "The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face," was celebrated for her emotive ballads that blended R&B, jazz, folk, and pop, and made history as the first artist to win the Grammy Award for Record of the Year in consecutive years.
openai_trending_reason: Roberta Flack is trending because she has passed away at the age of 88, prompting widespread media coverage of her influential music career and iconic songs like "Killing Me Softly with His Song." Her emotive style and success as a pioneering artist in blending genres have resonated with many, leading to tributes and remembrances across various platforms.

title: 31st_Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards
summary: The article describes the 31st Screen Actors Guild Awards, which will be held on February 23, 2025, at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles and hosted by Kristen Bell. It details that "Wicked" led film nominations with 5 nods while "Shōgun" dominated television with 5 nominations and 4 wins, with the ceremony streaming on Netflix and Jane Fonda receiving the SAG Life Achievement Award.
extract: The 31st Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards, honoring the best achievements in film and television performances for the year 2024, were presented on February 23, 2025, at the Shrine Auditorium and Expo Hall in Los Angeles, California. For the second year in a row, the ceremony streamed live on Netflix, starting at 8:00 p.m. EST / 5:00 p.m. PST. Actress Kristen Bell hosted the ceremony for the second time since the 24th ceremony in 2018.

title: Jane_Fonda
summary: This article provides a comprehensive overview of Jane Fonda, the American actress and political activist born in 1937, detailing her extensive filmography spanning six decades, numerous accolades including two Academy Awards, and her notable political activism during the Vietnam War. The text chronicles her career trajectory from her screen debut in 1960 through her dramatic and comedic roles, her Broadway performances, television work, and her return to acting after a 15-year hiatus.
extract: Jane Seymour Fonda is an American actress and activist. Recognized as a film icon, Fonda's work spans several genres and over six decades of film and television. She is the recipient of numerous accolades, including two Academy Awards, two British Academy Film Awards, seven Golden Globe Awards, and a Primetime Emmy Award as well as nominations for a Grammy Award and two Tony Awards. Fonda also received the Honorary Palme d'Or in 2007, the AFI Life Achievement Award in 2014, the Golden Lion for Lifetime Achievement in 2017, the Cecil B. DeMille Award in 2021, and the Screen Actors Guild Life Achievement Award in 2025.
anthropic_trending_reason: Jane Fonda is trending because she received the Screen Actors Guild Lifetime Achievement Award and delivered a politically charged speech that made headlines. During her acceptance speech, she emphasized that "empathy is not weak or woke" and encouraged activism, sparking discussion about celebrities using award platforms for political messages.
openai_trending_reason: Jane Fonda is trending because she delivered a powerful and politically charged speech while accepting the Life Achievement Award at the 2025 SAG Awards, where she emphasized the significance of empathy and activism. Her remarks resonated with current social issues and sparked discussions surrounding the concepts of empathy and being "woke."

title: Aimee_Lou_Wood
summary: This article provides a biographical overview of English actress Aimee Lou Wood, born in 1994, highlighting her rise to fame through Netflix's "Sex Education" (which earned her a BAFTA) and detailing her subsequent career in film and television, including roles in "The White Lotus" and stage productions like "Cabaret."
extract: Aimee Lou Wood is an English actress. After early stage roles in Mary Stuart (2016–2017) and People, Places and Things (2017), Wood made her screen debut on the Netflix series Sex Education (2019–2023), which won her a British Academy Television Award for Best Female Comedy Performance.
anthropic_trending_reason: Aimee Lou Wood is trending because she is currently starring in season 3 of the popular HBO series "The White Lotus," where she has been candid about the challenging seven-month filming experience in Thailand, describing it as "so extreme" and "intense." The British actress, known for her award-winning role in Netflix's "Sex Education," has garnered attention for discussing the intimate scenes in the new season and her collaboration with intimacy coordinators, marking her continued rise in high-profile television projects.

title: Walton_Goggins
summary: This article provides an overview of American actor Walton Goggins' career, highlighting his prominent roles in television series like "The Shield," "Justified," "Fallout," and "The White Lotus," as well as his work in films such as "The Hateful Eight" and "Django Unchained." The article also mentions his Emmy nominations and his work as a producer, including co-producing the Academy Award-winning short film "The Accountant."
extract: Walton Sanders Goggins Jr. is an American actor. He has starred in various television series, including The Shield (2002–2008), Justified (2010–2015), Vice Principals (2016–2017), The Righteous Gemstones (2019–present), Invincible (2021–present), Fallout (2024–present), and The White Lotus (2025). He was nominated for the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series for Justified, and for the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series for Fallout.
text:
{{Short description|American actor (born 1971)}}
{{Use American English|date=August 2019}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2023}}
{{Infobox person
| name               = Walton Goggins
| image              = Walton Goggins by Gage Skidmore.jpg
| caption            = Goggins in 2015
| birth_name         = Walton Sanders Goggins Jr.
| birth_date         = {{Birth date and age|1971|11|10}}
| birth_place        = [[Birmingham, Alabama]], U.S.
| occupation         = Actor
| years_active       = 1989–present
| spouse             = {{ubl|{{marriage|Leanne Kaun|2001|2004|end=d.}}|{{marriage|Nadia Conners|2011}}}}
| children           = 1
| education          = [[Georgia Southern University]]
}}
'''Walton Sanders Goggins Jr.''' (born November 10, 1971)<ref name="tvg" /> is an American actor. He has starred in various television series, including ''[[The Shield]]'' (2002–2008), ''[[Justified (TV series)|Justified]]'' (2010–2015), ''[[Vice Principals]]'' (2016–2017), ''[[The Righteous Gemstones]]'' (2019–present), ''[[Invincible (TV series)|Invincible]]'' (2021–present), ''[[Fallout (American TV series)|Fallout]]'' (2024–present), and ''[[The White Lotus]]'' (2025).<ref>{{cite web |last1=Porter |first1=Rick |title='Fallout' Teaser Showcases Post-Apocalyptic World |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/tv/tv-news/fallout-tv-series-first-teaser-amazon-1235708749/ |website=The Hollywood Reporter |date=December 2, 2023}}</ref> He was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series]] for ''Justified'', and for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series]] for ''Fallout''.

Goggins starred in and co-produced the [[Academy Award]]–winning short film ''[[The Accountant (2001 film)|The Accountant]]'' (2001).<ref name="Vulture-VicePrincipals-2016">{{cite news|last1=Wilson Hunt|first1=Stacey|title=Walton Goggins on 25 Years of Playing 'That Guy'|url=https://www.vulture.com/2016/07/walton-goggins-on-25-years-of-playing-that-guy.html|access-date=July 15, 2016|work=[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]|date=July 15, 2016}}</ref> He has also featured in feature films, such as ''[[Predators (film)|Predators]]'' (2010), ''[[Lincoln (film)|Lincoln]]'', ''[[Django Unchained]]'' (both 2012), ''[[The Hateful Eight]]'' (2015), ''[[Maze Runner: The Death Cure]]'', ''[[Tomb Raider (film)|Tomb Raider]]'', and ''[[Ant-Man and the Wasp]]'' (all 2018).

==Early life==
Goggins was born in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], the son of Janet Long and Walton Sanders Goggins Sr.<ref name=tvg>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/walton-goggins/bio/178811/ |title=Walton Goggins |magazine=[[TV Guide]] |access-date=April 29, 2016 |archive-date=April 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430031314/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/walton-goggins/bio/178811 |url-status=dead}}</ref> He was raised in [[Lithia Springs, Georgia|Lithia Springs]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], a suburb of [[Atlanta]], and graduated from [[Lithia Springs High School]] and attended [[Georgia Southern University]] for a year.<ref name=Vulture-VicePrincipals-2016/>

==Career==
Goggins worked for a valet car parking service and various restaurants in [[Los Angeles]].<ref name=Vulture-VicePrincipals-2016/> After starring in a few roles in Georgia, he met [[Ray McKinnon (actor)|Ray McKinnon]] while filming ''[[Murder in Mississippi (film)|Murder in Mississippi]]''.

Goggins played [[Shane Vendrell]] in the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] [[drama series|drama]] series ''[[The Shield]]''. He formed the production company [[Ginny Mule Pictures]], which produced four films: ''[[The Accountant (2001 film)|The Accountant]]'' (a short film which won an Academy Award for Live Action Short Film); ''[[Chrystal (film)|Chrystal]]'' (Sundance Dramatic Competition); ''[[Randy and the Mob]]'' and ''[[That Evening Sun (film)|That Evening Sun]]'' (which won the [[South by Southwest]] Special Jury Prize). They later created the drama series ''[[Rectify]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.avclub.com/article/walton-goggins-68464 |title=Interview: Walton Goggins |newspaper=[[The A.V. Club]] |first=Emily |last=VanDerWerff |date=January 31, 2012 |access-date=September 16, 2019}}</ref> Goggins was set to play the lead and [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]] had bought the pilot script, written by McKinnon, a role which went to [[Aden Young]], when the series later went to [[SundanceTV]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://theweek.com/articles/445977/rectify-successor-mad-men-youve-been-looking |title=Rectify is the successor to Mad Men you've been looking for |magazine=[[The Week]] |first=Scott |last=Meslow |date=June 20, 2014 |access-date=March 6, 2015}}</ref>

Goggins played Boyd Crowder in the pilot episode for the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] drama series ''[[Justified (TV series)|Justified]]'', while filming a major supporting role as a deadly death row inmate being hunted by the [[Predator (alien)|titular antagonists]] in the film ''[[Predat
anthropic_trending_reason: Walton Goggins is trending because he's currently starring in Season 3 of HBO's acclaimed series "The White Lotus" as the complex character Rick, which has generated significant viewer interest. His performance is drawing attention for the character's mysterious backstory and his intimate scenes with co-star Carrie Coon, with audiences and critics analyzing Rick's motivations and emotional depth just two episodes into the new season.
